sub_points: Immunocompromised patients with low CD4(+) lymphocyte counts are particularly susceptible to infection

Infectious Agents.text: C. gattiihas been mostly isolated from decomposing wood in tropical and subtropical areas, predominantly affecting immunocompetent patients
Usually occurs as consequence of hematogenous dissemination of yeasts, after inhalation exposure, or secondary to skin injury caused by untreated wood

Site.text: Finger and facial sites are particularly common sites in nonimmunocompromised hosts, resembling sporotrichoid pattern
Infection localized to trunk and lower extremities; multiple lesions are frequently seen in immunocompromised hosts

Presentation.text: Occurs most often in immunocompromised (leukemic, transplant, and AIDS) patients or those on immunosuppressivesAIDS when CD4 cell count falls below 100 cells/mL

Presentation.text: Expanded clinicomorphologic spectrum and lack of pathognomonic skin lesions make diagnosis difficult
Skin lesions typically appear as pedunculated, dome-shaped papules with umbilicated center known as molluscum-like lesions
Other conspicuous skin features include nodules, ulcers, plaques, pustules, bullous lesions, purpura, erythematous swelling, panniculitis, draining sinus, granulomas, and cellulitis
Cellulitis is more often sign of dissemination than of primary cutaneous disease and carries high risk of mortality

Treatment.text: Long-term therapy and follow-up is recommended to prevent relapses
Limited pulmonary or CC in immunocompetent patients without CNS involvement: Fluconazole, itraconazole
Disseminated cryptococcosis: Amphotericin B and flucytosine as primary induction therapy followed by fluconazole consolidation therapy

Prognosis.text: Skin involvement in immunosuppressed patients is marker of disseminated cryptococcosis
Mortality rate of 80% in 2 years without treatment
Treatment with amphotericin and flucytosine reduces mortality by 10-20%

Histoplasmosis.text: No true capsule (pseudocapsule), 2- to 4-μm yeasts, stains mucicarmine negative, and often numerous within macrophages without as striking of peripheral halo as in crypto

Lobomycosis.text: Thick-walled yeasts that form long chains of rounded and hyaline cells joined by small tubules and thick, birefringent cell wall

Paracoccidioidomycosis.text: Roundish cells with double membranes that are birefringent with multiple narrow neck buds resembling mariner's wheel

Blastomycosis.text: Thick-walled spores (8-15 μm in size) with characteristic broad-based budding in patients that are usually not immunosuppressed (vs. crypto, histo, cocci)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Granulomatous inflammation with varying size of yeasts freely present in small clear spaces, histiocytes, and giant cells

Alkaptonuria.text: Autosomal recessive genetic disease in which there is lack of HGO activity due to mutation ofHGDgene on chromosome 3q
HGA builds up in body and deposits in connective tissues (cartilage, tendons, sclerae)
HGA oxidizes to benzoquinones, which form melanin-like polymers called ochre pigment, thus causing darkening of tissue at sites of HGA deposition and darkening of urine when left standing

Over years, HGA deposition causes destruction of cartilage, tendons, ligaments, heart valves, and muscles, due to any of several possible theoriesHGA is chemical irritant, inducing inflammation directly or secondary to its oxidation, eventually causing more rapid degeneration of jointsOchre pigment polymers or HGA itself bind to connective tissue macromolecules, altering structural integrity of tissueInhibition of lysyl hydroxylase, which is required for connective tissue cross-linking through currently unclear mechanism
sub_points: HGA is chemical irritant, inducing inflammation directly or secondary to its oxidation, eventually causing more rapid degeneration of joints
Ochre pigment polymers or HGA itself bind to connective tissue macromolecules, altering structural integrity of tissue
Inhibition of lysyl hydroxylase, which is required for connective tissue cross-linking through currently unclear mechanism

Exogenous Ochronosis.text: Most commonly induced by topical hydroquinone in skin-lightening creams used to treat melasma
Other implicated products are those containing resorcinol, phenol, mercury, and picric acid, as well as antimalarial drugs
These compounds may inhibit HGO, leading to accumulation of HGA in papillary dermis and ochre pigment formation and deposition
